html:
Best Overall

Stacked Skincare Dermaplaning Exfoliation Tool

This facial razor is versatile, easy to use, and great for precision. The aluminum handle is lightweight, and the razor has an acute blade, allowing you to remove hair in one swipe.

Stacked Skincare rating: 4.8/5 stars

An ELLE editor says: “This is my favorite facial razor—it’s sharp, is super lightweight, and never causes any irritation.”—Katie Berohn, ELLE beauty editor

Most Reliable Brand

Tweezerman Facial Razor

Pros
  • Great quality for the price
Cons
  • Blades may dull quickly

If you want to be able to get super precise when using a razor for your brows, this facial razor is the best tool for the job. The blade isn’t surrounded by any material, so you’re able to maneuver the razor more easily around your face.

Nordstrom rating: 4.2/5

An ELLE editor says: “If you’re looking for a super luxe facial razor, this one from Tweezerman feels expensive. It has a nice weight to it and is entirely stainless steel, so it looks nice and is able to get every single hair. I do feel that I need to do more passes with this razor than some others I’ve tried, however.”—Katie Berohn

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Easiest to Grip

Flamingo Refillable Dermaplane Razor

Cons
  • Hard to get precise swipes

This razor’s curved angle helps you navigate your eyebrow’s arches easily. It’s also equipped with a grippy fingerpad and handle to make sure that your fingers don’t slip—which is especially important in an area like your eyebrows, where mess-ups would be nothing short of devastating.

Flamingo rating: 4.6/5

An ELLE editor says: “If you’re looking for a super luxe facial razor, this one from Tweezerman feels expensive. It has a nice weight to it and is entirely stainless steel, so it looks nice and is able to get every single hair.” —Katie Berohn

Best Value Find

Tinkle Eyebrow Razor

Pros
  • Made only with eyebrow hairs in mind
Cons
  • Extra sharp blades need to be used carefully

Tinkle eyebrow razors are a fan-favorite, with over 100,000 five-star reviews on Amazon. They’re easy to use and the blade isn’t surrounded by any material, so you’re able to be extremely precise as you cull hair.

Amazon rating: 4.6/5

An Amazon reviewer says: “I have been buying these for years! And any skin care expert or esthetician will tell you this is the best brand. The price is right for these and they work well, are sharp but I have never cut myself. I love this for any of those stray lip or chin hairs, but I also use them to get rid of peach fuzz and exfoliate.”

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Best Reusable Option

Sephora Collection Metal Facial Razor

Pros
  • Sleek shape and weighted handle are easy to use
Cons
  • Some say the blades are difficult to change

Sephora’s facial razor is sleek and versatile. The angle and position of the blade helps ensure that you’re able to get every hair, and it removes fuzz in one clean sweep.

Sephora rating: 4.2/5

A Sephora reviewer says: “Finally, a quality facial razor. It is heavier which makes it easier to use and keep your hold stable. It is well priced as it comes with extra blades. It comes in a case so that it is less likely to get lost.”

Best for Facial Hair Removal

Gillette Venus Dermaplaning Tool

Pros
  • Doesn't drag or catch on skin

Since Venus is beloved for their razors, it makes sense that their facial razor would be top-notch. With a precise razor head and a curved handle for easy gripping, this razor is able to easily shape the harder-to-reach hairs around your eyebrows. Target rating: 4.7/5A Target reviewer says: “This facial razor works well for me and hasn’t caused irritation. I use it for dermaplaning, and don’t find that it drags or catches like some others can. I feel that I can get a few uses out of each cartridge before the blade dulls, which is great.

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Best Professional-Grade Razor

Versed Instant Gratification

Pros
  • Easy to use for beginners
Cons
  • Some find the handle hard to grip

Versed’s facial razor is made to be professional-grade, and it delivers. The single-edged blade helps you achieve an extremely close shave. Plus, the handle features a no-slip grip, so you don’t need to be worried about mistakes.

Versed rating: 4.6/5

A Versed reviewer says: “I bought this a few days back and being a beginner, this tool was so easy to use and it’s safe for sensitive skin as well. I have never touched my face with any blade before. This was my first time ever and I loved it.”

Best Disposable Option

Schick Hydro Silk Touch-Up Exfoliating Dermaplaning Tool

Pros
  • Easy to customize for more precision

If you’re looking for a disposable facial razor, this one is best in class. Not only is it extremely sharp and easy to use, it’s also customizable, since it comes with a precision cover specifically designed for eyebrow shaping. When you put the cover on, you’re able to target individual hairs much more easily.

Amazon rating: 4.6/5

An Amazon reviewer says: “I love these. They’re a combination of a mini razor (but doesn’t cut too close) and a trimmer, and they last a long time, but I don’t use them often or over a large range of skin. I use them to trim my brows (under the brow) when I don’t have time to pluck. They do a wonderful job.”

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

Meet the expert

When would be the best time to reach for a razor instead of other brow tools?

If you’ve been experiencing irritation with other hair removal methods, it might be a good time to try using an eyebrow razor. “If you’re looking for a quick and easy at-home method to groom your brows, a razor can be a convenient choice,” says Akram. “However, I recommend proceeding with caution, since improper use can cause uneven or patchy skin. In this case it might be better to explore other brow care methods.”

Advertisement - Continue Reading Below

How do you use a razor for eyebrows?

Eyebrow razors can look daunting, but luckily, they’re much easier to use than they look. “To use a razor for your brows, start by holding the skin around your eyebrows taut to create a flat, firm surface,” says Akram. “Shave using small strokes, moving in the direction of hair growth. Be sure to go slowly and carefully around the brow area to reduce the risk of cuts.”
